content:
Scary mistake. But hopefully you can get the messages back.

If you did not touch the Trash folder you should find your messages there.

  • https://mail.google.com/mail/
  • Click on "more" in the list of label names to the left
  • Click on the Trash label
  • Select the messages you want to move back to Inbox
  • Click the Move icon and then select Inbox as the target label
creator: wsmwk

content: I presume it was an IMAP account. Unfortunately, IMAP always syncs to the server, so when a message is deleted, it is deleted at the server. You might check gmail online to see if the messages are in the trash folder, as I think gmail keeps trash for 30 days.
creator: davidsk

content:
If however you had also deleted everything from Trash, you should find your messages in All Mail.

  • https://mail.google.com/mail/
  • Click on "more" in the list of label names to the left
  • Click on All Mail
  • Select the messages you want to move back to Inbox. For completeness you may want to select EVERYTHING, which means click the selection box just below the "From" button, then click "Select all nnnnn conversations in All Mail"
  • All Mail has an icon to move messages to Inbox (unlike the Trash dialog). Click the "Move to Inbox" icon.
creator: wsmwk

content: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/imap-synchronization describes how imap works.
creator: wsmwk

content: The "All Mail" route makes it easy to select all messages, so it might be easier than the Trash instructions.

Inoltre succede casualmente su più pc differenti su più account differenti, cosa che mi fa dubitare sia dovuta a profili corrotti, ma più probabilmente a TB. Tendenzialmente ti direi di no. Con IMAP il client è costantemente connesso al server perché il protocollo prevede una operatività in tempo reale.

Però se hai una casistica ampia, probabilmente è meglio se apri una segnalazione di bug su Bugzilla https://bugzilla.mozilla.org dove la questione può essere esaminata da esperti mentre questo, ricordo, è un solo un forum per gli utenti.

creator: davidsk

content:
Checking the Settings » General » "Show only display name for people in my address book" check box has the effect of turning on "Prefer display name over message header" for all addresses in the address book.

Unchecking the Settings » General » "Show only display name for people in my address book" check box allows the current setting of "Prefer display name over message header" to apply on a case-by-case basis, which may or may not result in showing the display name from the message header.

What I'm looking for is a way to show the display name from the message header in all cases. It would be nice to be able to turn it fully on or fully off, which probably was the original intent of the Settings » General » "Show only display name for people in my address book" check box. Unfortunately, it only allows one to turn it on. It won't allow you to turn it fully off – temporarily or permanently – for all addresses.

---

BTW, there are four formats in which one can export address books. None of those formats include an indication of an address's "Prefer display name over message header" setting. I was hoping to export, run a script on the exported data, then re-import. But since that data isn't included in the export, that's kind of pointless.

content: I think the data should be compatible. On your old PC, the profile's name is in the profiles.ini file, which was at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird and the profile folder is in c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles. If there is only one folder there, that would be it, and the name probably ends in default or default-release. On the mac, you could use tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation and follow the prompts to move the profile into the mac.
creator: davidsk

content:
Please understand that what you are seeing is intentional from the Thunderbird developers, so complaining goes nowhere. As you may have discovered, the menu bar is hidden by default. My suggestion is to try their approach of living without the menu bar and using just the hamburger menu. For most issues, that works. However, if you want to keep the menu bar on top, there is a way to do that.

- click settings>general and scrollodown to config editor - search for toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets and change to true - then you need a folder named 'chrome' in profile, and a userChrome.css text file in the folder (with content shown below). - exit and restart TB and it should work, although I've sometimes found I have to restart TB twice to see changes in userChrome.css - Below is content for userChrome.css 

/*  #######    */ @namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");  #toolbar-menubar {   order: 1;              }  unified-toolbar {   order: 2;              }  #tabs-toolbar {   order: 3;               }
creator: davidsk

content:
Hamburger menu, ...

"Yes, I'd like a SuperBird with pickles, mayo, mustard. And cheese please."

I'm old school in that I follow the accepted practice of: 1) Windows Title Header - critical for when you need to grab the window and shift on your screen. 2) Main Menu Bar - never hidden, hidden menu's frustrate users more than unexpected design changes. 3) Main Toolbar - where you can put all the actions you use frequently. 4) Optional The Tabs, though I don't use them, preferring messages in their own window, so I can move them around and keep contents of other messages in sight as I compose a reply.

So I went with:[code]

  1. toolbar-menubar { order: 1; }
  2. tabs-toolbar { order: 2; }

unified-toolbar { order: 3; }/code

And hid the tabs and ended up with something much more useful looking. Is there a namespace for the "Message List Header" ? Or is that part of the main message list window?
creator: Colin.Warren

content: As a new user, my suggestion is to spend more time evaluating the options before seeking help, and if you're just trying to find a desirable email client, I suggest it may be wise to evaluate several at the same time. The strength of Thunderbird, of course, is that it is free to use. I do understand your frustration: people coming from Eudora complain that Thunderbird doesn't act like Eudora, people coming from WindowsLIve complain that Thunderbird doesn't act like WindowsLive, and the same from other clients. To share a few comments: conversation view can be turned off with a menu selection, and the order of messages can be easily changed in similar fashion, and Thunderbird also has the ability to show a count of unread messages on the toolbar from the settings menu. On the things you don't like, your suggestions should go to connect dot mozilla dot org to be reviewed, as this forum is only to assist in Thunderbird as it exists today. Thank you for sharing your comments. If you pursue features in depth, and feel comfortable with CSS, Thunderbird has significant customization capabilities.
creator: davidsk
